logTitle: IELTS Reading Log: Plant 'thermometer' triggers springtime growth

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Plant ‘thermometer’ triggers springtime growth by measuring night-time heat

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To cause or initiate the growth of plants that happens in the spring
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kích hoạt sự tăng trưởng mùa xuân

phase3Production.content: The warm rain triggers springtime growth in the desert.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A photoreceptor molecule in plant cells has been found to have a second job as a thermometer after dark...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A molecule that is sensitive to light

phase3Production.content: Rhodopsin is a photoreceptor molecule found in the retinas of our eyes.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...allowing plants to read seasonal temperature changes.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Cho phép cây cối 'đọc/nhận biết' (read) 'những thay đổi' (changes) 'nhiệt độ' (temperature) 'theo mùa' (seasonal)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To sense and interpret the variations in temperature that occur with the changing seasons
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Nhận biết những thay đổi nhiệt độ theo mùa

phase3Production.content: Migrating birds can read seasonal temperature changes to know when to fly south.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Scientists say the discovery could help breed crops that are more resilient to the temperatures expected to result from climate change.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Better able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions

phase3Production.content: These new materials are more resilient to heat and pressure.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...used by plants to detect light during the day...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To notice or discover the presence of light

phase3Production.content: The security camera is designed to detect light and motion.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...to become cellular temperature gauges that measure the heat of the night.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Instruments within a cell that measure and indicate temperature
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các thiết bị đo nhiệt độ tế bào

phase3Production.content: These molecules act as tiny cellular temperature gauges, telling the plant when it's warm enough to grow.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...phytochromes control genetic switches in response to temperature as well as light...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To regulate the mechanisms that turn genes on or off
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kiểm soát các công tắc di truyền

phase3Production.content: Scientists are learning how to control genetic switches to fight diseases.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...as well as light to dictate plant development.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Chi phối/quyết định' (dictate) 'sự phát triển của cây' (plant development)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To control or influence completely how a plant grows and changes
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Chi phối sự phát triển của thực vật

phase3Production.content: The amount of sunlight a plant receives can dictate its development and size.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the pace at which they change is ‘directly proportional to temperature’...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Tỷ lệ thuận trực tiếp với' (directly proportional to)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Having a relationship where as one amount increases, another amount increases at the same rate
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Tỷ lệ thuận trực tiếp với

phase3Production.content: The force needed to push the object is directly proportional to its mass.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the faster the molecular change – stimulating plant growth.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Kích thích' (stimulating) 'sự phát triển của cây' (plant growth)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Encouraging or causing plants to grow more
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Kích thích sự phát triển của thực vật

phase3Production.content: The new fertilizer is very effective at stimulating plant growth.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Farmers and gardeners have known for hundreds of years how responsive plants are to temperature...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Cây cối 'phản ứng/nhạy bén' (responsive) 'như thế nào' (how)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The degree to which plants react to a stimulus like temperature
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Mức độ phản ứng của thực vật

phase3Production.content: This study examines how responsive different crops are to drought conditions.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...warm winters cause many trees and flowers to bud early...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To produce small growths on a plant that develop into leaves or flowers earlier than usual

phase3Production.content: Due to the mild weather, the cherry blossoms began to bud early this year.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...something humans have long used to predict weather and harvest times for the coming year.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The times of year when crops are cut and collected from the fields

phase3Production.content: Climate change is making it harder for farmers to predict harvest times.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The latest research pinpoints for the first time a molecular mechanism in plants that reacts to temperature...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Chỉ ra chính xác' (pinpoints) 'lần đầu tiên' (for the first time)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To identify or discover something with great accuracy for the first time
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Lần đầu tiên chỉ ra chính xác

phase3Production.content: The new satellite data pinpoints for the first time the exact location of the shipwreck.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a molecular mechanism in plants that reacts to temperature...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A process involving molecules that produces a particular effect

phase3Production.content: Scientists are studying the molecular mechanism behind the disease.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: With weather and temperatures set to become ever more unpredictable due to climate change...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Increasingly difficult to predict or know what will happen

phase3Production.content: The global political situation is becoming ever more unpredictable.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...this light-sensing molecule also functions as the internal thermometer in plant cells could help us breed tougher crops.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Lai tạo' (breed) 'những giống cây trồng' (crops) 'cứng cáp hơn' (tougher)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To cultivate and develop new varieties of crops that are more durable and resistant to difficult conditions
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Lai tạo các giống cây trồng cứng cáp hơn

phase3Production.content: Scientists are working to breed tougher crops that can survive in dry climates.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘It is estimated that agricultural yields will need to double by 2050...’

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The amount of a crop that is produced from an area of land

phase3Production.content: The new farming techniques have significantly increased agricultural yields.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but climate change is a major threat to achieving this.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A significant danger or risk to something
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Một mối đe dọa lớn đối với

phase3Production.content: Pollution is a major threat to marine ecosystems.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Thermal stress reduces crop yields by around 10% for every one degree increase in temperature,’...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The pressure or strain on a plant or organism caused by extreme temperatures

phase3Production.content: Crops in this region are often affected by thermal stress during the summer.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Discovering the molecules that allow plants to sense temperature has the potential to accelerate the breeding of crops resilient to thermal stress and climate change.’

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make the process of developing new plant varieties happen more quickly

phase3Production.content: New genetic technologies can accelerate the breeding of disease-resistant plants.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In their active state, phytochrome molecules bind themselves to DNA to restrict plant growth.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The condition in which something is functioning or having an effect

phase3Production.content: The volcano has been in an active state for several months.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...phytochrome molecules bind themselves to DNA to restrict plant growth.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To attach themselves to the DNA molecule

phase3Production.content: Certain proteins can bind themselves to DNA to control gene expression.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...bind themselves to DNA to restrict plant growth.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Hạn chế' (restrict) 'sự phát triển của cây' (plant growth)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To limit the ability of a plant to grow or develop
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Hạn chế sự phát triển của thực vật

phase3Production.content: Lack of water will severely restrict plant growth.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This is how plants compete to escape each other’s shade.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To strive against others to get away from something

phase3Production.content: The seedlings in the dense forest compete to escape the shade and reach the sunlight.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Instead of a rapid deactivation following sundown, the molecules gradually change...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A fast process of making something no longer active or effective
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự vô hiệu hóa nhanh chóng

phase3Production.content: The system is designed for rapid deactivation in an emergency.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This is called ‘dark reversion’.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The process by which phytochrome molecules change from their active form back to their inactive form in the absence of light
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự đảo ngược trong bóng tối

phase3Production.content: The speed of dark reversion in phytochromes is dependent on temperature.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the rate at which phytochromes revert to their inactive state during the night is a direct measure of temperature...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Trở lại' (revert to) 'trạng thái không hoạt động' (their inactive state)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To go back to a non-functioning or dormant condition
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Trở lại trạng thái không hoạt động

phase3Production.content: After the alarm, the security system will automatically revert to its inactive state.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...is a direct measure of temperature.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'thước đo trực tiếp của' (a direct measure of)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A way of measuring something that is directly related to it, without intermediate steps
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Một thước đo trực tiếp của

phase3Production.content: The number of tickets sold is a direct measure of the event's popularity.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the molecules spend more time in their active, growth-suppressing state.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A condition in which the process of growth is prevented or restrained
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Trạng thái ức chế tăng trưởng

phase3Production.content: During winter, many plants enter a dormant, growth-suppressing state.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...phytochromes rapidly reach an inactive state and detach themselves from the plant’s DNA...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To separate or unfasten oneself from something

phase3Production.content: The rocket's booster stage will detach itself from the main capsule after two minutes.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...allowing genes to be expressed and plant growth to resume.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Cho phép 'các gen' (genes) 'được biểu hiện' (to be expressed)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Allowing the process by which information from a gene is used in the synthesis of a functional gene product

phase3Production.content: This process allows certain genes to be expressed, leading to cell differentiation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and plant growth to resume.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sự phát triển 'tiếp tục lại' (to resume)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: For the process of growing to begin again after a pause
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Sự tăng trưởng tiếp tục trở lại

phase3Production.content: After the rain, the plants' growth began to resume.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and co-opted the biological network already used for light-based growth during the biological downtime of night.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To take over and use a pre-existing biological system for a new purpose
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Tiếp quản mạng lưới sinh học

phase3Production.content: The virus co-opted the cell's own machinery to replicate itself.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Some plants mainly use day length as an indicator of the season.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The period of time during each 24 hours when the sun is above the horizon

phase3Production.content: Many plants use the changing day length to determine when to flower.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Other species, such as daffodils, have considerable temperature sensitivity...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A high degree of responsiveness to changes in temperature
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Độ nhạy cảm nhiệt độ đáng kể

phase3Production.content: Orchids are known for their considerable temperature sensitivity.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In fact, the discovery of the dual role of phytochromes provides the science behind a well-known rhyme...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Having two different functions or purposes

phase3Production.content: The manager has a dual role as both a leader and a mentor.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Oak trees rely much more on temperature, likely using phytochromes as thermometers to dictate development...’

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Dựa vào nhiều hơn' (rely much more on)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To depend on something to a greater extent

phase3Production.content: Modern navigation systems rely much more on GPS than on traditional maps.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...whereas ash trees rely on measuring day length to determine their seasonal timing.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The scheduling of biological events in relation to the seasons

phase3Production.content: The seasonal timing of bird migration is crucial for their survival.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a colder summer is likely to be a rain-soaked one.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Extremely wet due to a lot of rain

phase3Production.content: We returned from our hike with rain-soaked clothes and muddy boots.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: culmination of twelve years of research
lexicalItems.sourceContext: The new findings are the culmination of twelve years of research involving scientists from Germany, Argentina and the US, as well as the Cambridge team.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Kết quả đỉnh cao' (culmination) 'của 12 năm' (of twelve years) 'nghiên cứu' (of research)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The final and highest point or result of a long period of research
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Đỉnh cao của mười hai năm nghiên cứu

phase3Production.content: The Nobel Prize was the culmination of her long and distinguished career.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The work was done in a model system, using a mustard plant called Arabidopsis...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A non-human species that is extensively studied to understand particular biological phenomena, with the expectation that discoveries made will provide insight into the workings of other organisms

phase3Production.content: The fruit fly is a common model system for studying genetics.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Recent advances in plant genetics now mean that scientists are able to rapidly identify the genes...’

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: New discoveries or developments in a particular field
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những tiến bộ gần đây trong

phase3Production.content: Recent advances in medicine have led to new treatments for cancer.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and even alter their activity using precise molecular ‘scalpels,’...’

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To change the way something functions or works
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Thay đổi hoạt động của chúng

phase3Production.content: The drug is designed to alter the activity of specific enzymes in the brain.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...using precise molecular ‘scalpels,’ adds Wigge.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A metaphor for tools (like CRISPR) that can cut or edit genes with great accuracy at the molecular level
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Những 'con dao mổ' phân tử chính xác

phase3Production.content: Gene editing technologies like CRISPR act as precise molecular 'scalpels' to modify DNA.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Cambridge is uniquely well-positioned to do this kind of research...’

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Có 'vị thế tốt một cách độc đáo' (uniquely well-positioned)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be in a particularly advantageous or suitable position that others are not
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Có một vị thế đặc biệt thuận lợi

phase3Production.content: With its vast resources, the company is uniquely well-positioned to lead the market.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...as we have outstanding collaborators nearby who work on more applied aspects of plant biology...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People who work jointly on an activity or project and are exceptionally good
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các cộng tác viên xuất sắc

phase3Production.content: The project's success was due to a team of outstanding collaborators from different fields.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...who work on more applied aspects of plant biology...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The practical, real-world uses or parts of a subject

phase3Production.content: While he enjoyed the theory, she was more interested in the applied aspects of engineering.

lexicalItems.targetLexeme: transfer this new knowledge into the field
lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and can help us transfer this new knowledge into the field.’

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Chuyển giao' (transfer) 'kiến thức mới này' (this new knowledge) 'vào thực địa' (into the field)

phase2Annotation.phonetic: /trænsˈfɜː ðɪs njuː ˈnɒlɪdʒ ˈɪntuː ðə fiːld/
phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To take new information and apply it in a practical, real-world setting (like on a farm)
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Chuyển giao kiến thức mới này vào thực địa

phase3Production.content: The next step is to transfer this new knowledge from the laboratory into the field.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A photoreceptor molecule in plant cells has been found to have a second job as a thermometer after dark...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: When night has begun

phase3Production.content: It's not safe to walk through the park after dark.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: During the day, sunlight activates the molecules, slowing down growth.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Reducing the rate at which something increases in size

phase3Production.content: The cold weather is slowing down the growth of the spring vegetables.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: If a plant finds itself in shade, phytochromes are quickly inactivated...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In an area of comparative darkness and coolness produced by something blocking the light of the sun

phase3Production.content: It was too hot to sit in the sun, so we found a spot in the shade.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Light-driven changes to phytochrome activity occur very fast, in less than a second,’ says Wigge.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In a period of time shorter than one second; almost instantaneously

phase3Production.content: The camera's flash fires and is over in less than a second.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: At night, however, it’s a different story.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một câu chuyện khác (tình hình khác)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An idiom meaning that the situation is not the same as the one just mentioned

phase3Production.content: He's very quiet at work, but at parties, it's a different story.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Just as mercury rises in a thermometer, the rate at which phytochromes revert to their inactive state... is a direct measure of temperature,’ says Wigge.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Cũng giống như thủy ngân dâng lên

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A simile used to compare a process to the way mercury expands and moves up in a thermometer
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Cũng như thủy ngân dâng lên

phase3Production.content: Just as mercury rises with the heat, so does people's demand for ice cream.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and can flower months in advance during a warm winter.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To produce flowers several months earlier than the usual time

phase3Production.content: You need to book your tickets months in advance to get a good price.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A warmer spring, and consequently a higher likelihood of a hot summer, will result in oak leafing before ash.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A spring season with higher than average temperatures

phase3Production.content: A warmer spring means the flowers will bloom earlier this year.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and consequently a higher likelihood of a hot summer...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A greater probability or chance of something happening

phase3Production.content: There is a higher likelihood of rain this afternoon.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...will result in oak leafing before ash.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sẽ 'dẫn đến kết quả là' (result in)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To cause a particular situation to happen

phase3Production.content: The heavy rain will result in flooding in low-lying areas.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: A cold spring will see the opposite.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The reverse of what has just been mentioned

phase3Production.content: I thought the movie would be boring, but the opposite was true.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...research involving scientists from Germany, Argentina and the US...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Bao gồm các nhà khoa học từ

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Including or having as participants scientists from various places
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Với sự tham gia của các nhà khoa học từ

phase3Production.content: It was a huge international project involving scientists from over twenty countries.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but Wigge says the phytochrome genes necessary for temperature sensing are found in crop plants as well.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Plants that are grown as crops for food, such as wheat, rice, and maize

phase3Production.content: The research could be applied to important crop plants like wheat and barley.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...scientists are able to rapidly identify the genes controlling these processes in crop plants...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Xác định một cách nhanh chóng

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To recognize or find something quickly

phase3Production.content: The new software allows doctors to rapidly identify potential health risks.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...identify the genes controlling these processes in crop plants...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các gen kiểm soát những quá trình này

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The specific genes that regulate or direct these biological functions
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các gen kiểm soát các quá trình này

phase3Production.content: Scientists have isolated the genes controlling the plant's flowering time.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ‘Cambridge is uniquely well-positioned to do this kind of research...’

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Thực hiện loại nghiên cứu này

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To conduct or perform this type of scientific investigation
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Thực hiện loại nghiên cứu này

phase3Production.content: You need a specialized lab to do this kind of research.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and can help us transfer this new knowledge into the field.’

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Recently discovered information and understanding about a subject

phase3Production.content: The conference was a great opportunity to share new knowledge with colleagues.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...long used to predict the coming season...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The next season of the year (spring, summer, autumn, or winter)

phase3Production.content: Farmers are preparing their fields for the coming season.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...will result in oak leafing before ash.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The process of a tree or plant producing leaves

phase3Production.content: The leafing of the trees is a sure sign that spring has arrived.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: An international team of scientists led by the University of Cambridge has discovered...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A group of people from different countries working together

phase3Production.content: An international team was assembled to tackle the global health crisis.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The new findings, published in the journal Science, show that...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Recently discovered information resulting from research

phase3Production.content: The new findings challenge previous theories about the planet's formation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The warmer it is, the faster the molecular change – stimulating plant growth.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sự thay đổi ở cấp độ phân tử

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A change that occurs at the level of molecules

phase3Production.content: Heating the substance causes a molecular change that alters its properties.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The latest research pinpoints for the first time a molecular mechanism...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The most recent and up-to-date scientific investigation

phase3Production.content: According to the latest research, regular exercise can improve brain function.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Key crops such as wheat and rice are sensitive to high temperatures.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Các loại cây trồng chủ chốt

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The most important crops grown for food or economic purposes

phase3Production.content: Wheat, rice, and maize are key crops that feed billions of people worldwide.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...says lead researcher Dr Philip Wigge from Cambridge’s Sainsbury Laboratory.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The principal scientist in charge of a research project

phase3Production.content: The lead researcher presented the team's findings at the conference.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...has the potential to accelerate the breeding of crops...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have the inherent ability or capacity to do something in the future

phase3Production.content: This new technology has the potential to revolutionize the energy industry.
